I’ve been rewatching some shojo that I really enjoyed when I first started getting into anime, and Special A happened to make that list. Unfortunately, this anime has a lot of flaws that I didn’t see when I was in middle school! It’s a fun romance if you’re younger or just getting into anime, but after seeing quite a bit of shojo, this anime has a lot going against it. 
For one, characterization is lacking, especially for surrounding characters. In other shows with similar dynamics, such as Ouran or Maid-Sama, the background characters have a lot more depth compared to the cast in this show.


The plot is slower-paced, making some of the episodes drag, and Kei, the main love interest, puts all the responsibility on Hikari to discover his feelings for her. (Spoiler: she can’t read minds!) This is charming for about three episodes. It’s hard to sympathize with the male lead when he makes no attempt to convey his feelings, yet gets frustrated at being misunderstood. 


In Maid-Sama, the closest comparison for me to this show, at least Usui Takumi makes it more obvious he has feelings for Ayuzawa and appears more patient with her denseness. Kei barely does anything besides looking shocked when Hikari does something he likes, or seems pissed off/possessive on the flipside, giving Hikari (and the viewers) emotional whiplash. 


Because of the underdeveloped characters, the frequent, more serious turns in the plot just cannot be taken seriously. The humor in this show is the strong suit, but with the plot developments, the conflicts are cheesy, over-the-top, and fairly transparent. There are also some classist undertones that go unaddressed/can’t be offset by the main characters. In Ouran, Haruhi’s character offered the “commoner” point of view, which worked well to humor and ridicule the portrayed aristocracy. There is no such character in Special A, often making the plot about rich people being rich. 


Despite this criticism, Hikari is not the MOST annoying lead in shojo. The humor and cute moments made me remember why I thought this show was so charming. Though I don’t think my opinion of it is very high, objectively, it could be fun for a shojo-lover.

Special A is an anime that is near and dear to my heart. I’ve grown quite fond of it, mainly because of how wonderful the characters are. This anime is full of ups and downs—laughs, fun, confusion, sadness… The best part of this anime is the fact that, although there are cliché elements, there are some great things that set this apart from some other shoujo anime out there.
The story isn’t, by any means, that unique, but it is enjoyable and comes across the way that it’s meant to. Once again, there’s the school setting that we all know—it seems ever-present in shoujo—but there issomething unique about this school. That’s the special class that the main characters are in. I found this appealing, but some people might not agree.


Special A slides pretty well between fun, slice-of-life moments and seriousness. The plot is low-key and relaxed, unable to really be explained in a concrete way. The best part of this anime’s plot, though, is how comedy and romance is executed. The jokes are almost always got me laughing, and the little romantic moments made my heart flutter.


There is, however, a problem with the pacing. The main part of the story keeps getting pushed near the end, stretching the story out to the point where some people might just lose interest. Special A starts slow, gets better near the middle, and slows down again before the last hoorah.


I actually find the art style here quite favorable. It’s pleasing to the eyes and better than some things I’ve seen. The characters are tall and lanky, as per usual for the shoujo style. Although it seemed taken too far when I started watching, the style grew on me. All of the boys are extremely handsome; I’m quite fond of the character designs, as well.


Everything gets fuzzy and colorful during sweet moments. I actually find this quite cute, and am not annoyed by it.


The only thing that bothers me with the art is the fact that, more than once, you can easily spot times when the animators started experimenting. Eyes have more lashes, faces are drawn a bit differently, etc. I thought this was really unprofessional. The artwork is still good, but the random changing isn’t appealing.


Openings were pretty well done. I’m really fond of the first one, more so than the second OP, but both were catchy and fit the mood of the anime. The music during the show fit wonderfully, as well. Voice acting is good—the boy’s voices were particularly seductive, if I do say so myself.


The characters in Special A are some of my favorites. They are all so human, with so many emotions and such dimension in their personalities. When you realize what they’ve been through, and what goes on in their heads, you feel an unbreakable bond with them.


Yahiro, one of my favorites, comes across one way, only to have his motives explained in a heart-wrenching twist. Akira and Tadashi are a perfect, hilarious and emotional pair. Megumi, Ryuu, and Jun are lovely friends and great characters.


The true main characters, Hikari and Kei, make an awesome, unique pair. Hikari, competitive and a little thick (but adorable), harbors resentment towards Kei because he’s always in first place. Kei comes across as your normal jerk of a love interest—handsome, cold, calculating, perfect—but, while his perfection at most things is sometimes annoying, it becomes apparent that he has some flaws to him, too. Because they added personality to him, and made his love for Hikari so darn sweet, he’s become one of my favorite characters.


Some things that I didn’t find favorable is the fact that everyone was so privileged, the fact that they were all so popular, and the fact that they pretty much got to do whatever they wanted without problems. What’s also annoying is the fact that this was never explained very well.


There is another thing that I must mention. My main problem with this anime is the ending. I was looking for something really big, something that would make me feel accomplished, but in the end, I felt that something was missing, and that tarnished the experience a little.


Despite the flaws, Special A is currently one of my favorite shoujo anime, simply because it harbors so many wonderful emotions and just has a magical quality about it.


If you’re looking for something funny with sweet romance and great characters, I wouldn’t hesitate to try Special A out. It’s a great anime. I hope that, if you try it, you enjoy it as much as I did.


(At the moment, I have never read the manga, but will be reading it soon. I will edit my review once I finish.)

*some spoilers, but not major*
Special A isn't a very 'special' plot. Basically the top seven pupils of quite a high-ranking school are immediately placed into 'Special A', a group where they do not (seem) have to attend classes, and they have their own area of the school to themselves.
The thing that bugs me about Special A is the fact I don't actually like the protagonists that much. The whole 'competitive' thing, while funny to watch, was unbelievably aggrivating, especially when it came to her finding herself liking Kei back and realising she'd 'lost' the competition between them because of it.
I find Kei a bit tooaloof and just arrogant for my liking. Saying that, I do like that in some characters, but I just find him a little too tiresome and boring for my liking. For me to like a main, especially shoujo, male character, there has to be a little bit more in him, so maybe having flaws, aside from the whole fact of him loving her ( oh please, like thats not happened before in a shoujo manga ), would have enabled me to warm to him a little more.


I liked Hikari, in theory. I thought her sweet and lovably clueless. But as the series went on, I found her cluelessness becoming more and more irritating.


Saying this, you'll probably wonder why I gave this anime such a high mark. To be honest, it's the supporting characters. Suprisingly, I loved the other members of Special A and their stories. 


While it's essentially about Kei and Hikari, romance follows almost all of the rest of the group (Jun, Megumi, Akira, Tadashi and Ryuu). You will laugh at moments, and at others you will clutch at your heart for the tenderness of it.

The music is beautiful, and suits the anime to perfection.


All in all, I'd recommend you to watch this, but don't expect a stellar plot and brilliant main characters.

Although the art was fantastic, it was unsuccessful in trying to cover up the mediocre plotline, and unoriginal characters. Hikari is like every other shoujo character; she's kind, energetic, pretty, feminine, smart and yet boyish at the same time. The only fault that the mangaka tries to portray is that she's dense, which isn't really that big of a fault. Basically, she's too perfect, and she has two guys chasing her after the first five episodes. She fits a category of 2D characters; Mary Sue. The storyline is also unoriginal. Oh yeah, the girl can't be too perfect, so a guy character ALWAYS has tobeat her. Most of us can't even possibly achieve 2nd place in a prestigious school, have time to flirt and fool around, AND do competitive fighting. Do they even LEARN anything in the class? All that happens is that they lounge around drinking tea and having fun, which is probably the opposite of a special class. 

Oh a guy HAS to fall in love with her, but if she liked him back, that wouldn't make a story. So the mangaka tosses in density, which is very much stereotypical. It's just uneventful, with the audience waiting for the 'big kiss' which isn't very surprising. I haven't watched all of it, but I can guess that they'll kiss at the last episode, with fireworks, and everyone's happy! The end.

Big whoop'd do. Anyone can write a clichéd story like that. It's boring, especially when the audience watches it over and over again. Instead, couldn't the main character be ugly? Or maybe dumb? Just something that makes her different from other shoujo characters, because I swear, they're all the same with different names. That's it. 

Now, onto Takashima Kei. He's hot, smart, rich, and athletic, but with a bad attitude that doesn't make readers dislike him, it just makes him even more lusted-after. Another stereotypical character. The hottie of the school HAS to fall in love with the protagonist. It's like...The unbreakable rule in clichéd stories. He's almost exactly like Hikari, only just an introvert. Huh, that'll be like falling in love with yourself...Scary.

Naturally, the audience knows little to NOTHING about the supporting characters(unless they go to Wikipedia). Y'know why? Because the protagonist HAS to take the spotlight all the fricken time. If the protagonist isn't in a single episode, it might as well be a CRIME for all the fan girls that protest. Basically, the supporting characters' lives SURROUND the protagonist, like they have no life of their own. Just mindless drones that follow Hikari's every word.

It's criminal to have sympathy to the guy driving the fated couple apart! Y'know why?...I don't either. Why does the guy/girl that tries to drive the other couples away flawed? He's got ALL the flaws that the protagonist and antagonist don't have. He's so flawed that he's also 2D. Why can't the guy be funny, entertaining, and not extremely mean to the point where we want to kill him? 

My point is only this; PRETTY ART CANNOT COVER UP MARY SUE CHARACTERS AND CLICHÉD PLOTLINES!

Dubbed voice acting to the side, I loved the anime. It reminded me a lot of "Kaichou wa Maid-sama!" because of the whole boy-loves-girl and girl-loves-boy-back-but-refuses-to-admit-it kind of deal. If I had to describe Special A in a few words, it'd be: light-hearted, bubbly, upbeat, and cute. 
Story: 7/10
The theme is pretty much the typical slice of life about rich elite students (a group called S.A) and their high school life. Special A uses a conventional plot of an initial rivalry relationship blossoming into love. What is awesome about Special A is that the main couple's romance (Hikari and Kei) aren't the ONLY focus. It also features arcs for the side characters, so even if you're not loving the main couple, you can still follow the interesting side arcs :) Having fun arcs forside characters provides more variety plot-wise. 


Characters: 9/10

What I love about Special A is its abundance of fun and nicely developed characters. Unlike many shojos that have the spotlight on the main couple and then neglect the side characters (or give them too little depth etc), Special A manages to give all 7 students in S.A. enough screen time and development to make all of them seem real. There's animal-loving Ryuu, music geniuses Megumi and Jun, and the adorable Tadashi who has the funniest love-hate relationship with Akira. The side characters are not flimsy people just to fill up space.

As for the main character Hikari, she always tries her best (in academics, sports etc), but she can be RIDICULOUSLY dense and oblivious when it comes to realizing Kei's feelings. This can get frustrating, but she's so nice and down to earth you really can't hate her for it.

Kei is every girl's dream boyfriend: good-looking ;) smart, athletic and has an aura that just screams "COOL". But he also has a cute (almost vulnerable) side when it comes to Hikari. The two have a really endearing and cute love-hate relationship. 


Art: 7/10

The first thing you'll notice when watching Special A is OMG, THEY HAVE LOOOONG LEGS. Lanky frame aside, the characters are drawn quite nicely, a bit better than average. The way the S.A. greenhouse and some characters' mansions are drawn also adds grandeur.


Sound: 9/10

I really loved the second opening of Special A, because the 4 voice actors for the boys (Kei, Tadashi, Jun, Ryuu) are actually the ones singing the song! What is also really unique is that, each character has their own "character song" that is featured in certain episodes. (WATCH FOR MEGUMI'S, HER VOICE IS AMAZING)


Overall, Special is a really cute slice of life anime, the love-hate relationships are really amusing, the rivalries are cute, and the romance is sweet. I enjoyed watching Special A (and I think I've actually rewatched it a couple of times :D).

Well, like seemingly all romantic comedies, this one failed to wrap-it-up. Without trying spoiling anything, you'll see what I mean by the final episode. 
It's perplexing to me that a genre so devoted to love lacks exactly that when you come down to it. And honestly, the creators shouldn't be hesitant to put the hammer down and say, "This is who he/she ends up with. Love it or hate it." After all, this is a love story. I at least expected an, "I love you" at the end, but that was not to be.
Whew, with that out of the way let's get to the review:
Story:8

Nice and cute pretty much sums it up. Childhood friends and rivals growing up; well you can see where that's going.... Not too heavy, and pretty much sticking to the lighter side of life.


Art: 6

This would be a much lower score if they hadn't added in the beautiful pastel scenes during the lovey-dovey moments.


Sound: 7

Pretty good. Nothing amazing, solid voice acting, good ambient sounds too.


Character: 9

This was the most appealing part of the series to me. Characters, literally developed, since childhood should be pretty darn good. And they are. Each has a clear and defined personality that's easily distinguished from one another. 


Enjoyment: 7

Typical rom/com frustration will arise in you, for sure, but this would've been higher if the ignorance of Hikari and others were decreased. 


Overall: 7

A solid romantic anime. But, be warned: if you're the kind of person who needs to be told EXPLICITLY who ends up with whom (like me), be prepared for some hair-tearing.

I was so overjoyed when she finally realized her true feelings, that i almost fell out of my chair. I couldn't believe it took her that many episodes. 
In the first episode I thought the characters were drawnkind of awkwardly. Their frames were tall and skinny. In my opinion I would've preferred the girls shorter. The way the limbs were drawn also bothered me. They were mainly straight with no curves. You easily get accustomed to it though. Other than that things were fine. \n
The character development was great in this anime. Even though the main focus was Hikari and Kei, each episode was themed around a different character each time. You got to know a lot of background info which helped explain the character's personalities.\n
Overall it was a decent anime. Lots of laughs. Lots of fun. Pleasure to watch.

Special A is a typical anime about 7 high school kids who overtime develop a strong bond of friendship and romance. 
One of the major pros that kept me interested was the fact that it wasn't "filler-ish". You've all seen those school/slice-of-life anime who are really episodic in which every episode would feel completely random and out of the blue. Special A stuck to the storyline and the characters. 
Another positive key is that the story and all the characters are really positive. There are no events that leave you frustrated and wishing it should have gone differently. It really satisfied me knowing it wasa happy story and a happy ending. \n\n
Although at many times predictable, Special A is a somewhat cliche but yet it was an enjoyable ride by keeping its linear progression. Overall, it was an enjoyable anime. However, if you're looking at an anime that will leave you on the edge of your seat, this isn't the one. The ride is slow and peaceful
